results.title: Ren and Stimpy: the stupidest stories
results.brief_description: Ren’s faithful friend is always accused of being stupid so these three tales will do much to allay the rumours. “Stimpy’s big day”: Stimpy can’t resist the challenge to write a Gritty Kitty Litter Jingle to win 47 million dollars and a trip to Hollywood. “The Big shot”: Stimpy has his own show and lots of money, but can this take the place of a loyal but jealous friend. “Robin Hoek”: A Ren and Stimpy remake of a classic tale featuring Robin, the lovely Maid Moron and Friar Chuck.

results.title: Ren and Stimpy: the stinkiest stories
results.brief_description: Ren & Stimpy yuk it up. These three Ren & Stimpy episodes are definitely disgusting - but not genuinely offensive - more like a tickle from a wet hairball: “Ren’s toothache” - Ren’s teeth fall out because he doesn’t brush them, and there’s only one thing worse than a toothache - a visit from the Nerve Ending Fairy. “Nurse Stimpy” - Ren is ill. But have no fear, here comes Nurse Stimpy to attend to the patients every need - with a cure that is more dreadful than the disease. “The Cat that laid the golden hairball” - While Stimpy takes a vacation, Ren is left all to himself. He goes looking for something to do when he finds one of Stimpy’s hairballs. Ren throws a fit, but he soon changes after the price of hairballs goes up drastically. Stimpy becomes Ren’s hairball slave, and soon he runs out of hairballs. Against all odds, he keeps trying so that Ren has his pectorial muscle transplants. Video includes the short cartoon: “Powdered toastman”.

results.title: Ren and Stimpy: the classics
results.brief_description: These first-season classics transformed a scrawny, irritable chihuahua and his sweet but simple feline pal into rich, big-time cartoon celebrities: “Stimpy’s invention” - Stimpy invents a helmet for Ren that makes him happy. They sing the happy happy joy joy song and Ren smashes his helmet. Then he realizes that he is happy when he is mad. What else is in this show? - High Fashion Log for Girls, Dr. Stupid #3 “Untamed world” - Ren and Stimpy travel to the Galapagos Islands to discover a wide variety of marvellous creatures. “Space madness” - Commander Hoek and Cadet Stimpy are in space when Ren gets mad. Ren wants Stimpy to guard the mysterious History Erase Button. Video extra: Let Stimpy show you the way to get your day started right.

results.title: Remparts D'argile = Ramparts of Clay
results.brief_description:
Rima, a young orphan, lives in an Algerian village whose chief source of income is a salt mine. When the absentee owner refuses to raise the wages of the labourers, a strike is called. The mine owner calls the army to the rescue. Rima resorts to a stratagem to get rid of the troups. ‘Remparts d’argile’ was filmed in semi-documentary fashion in the Algerian village of Tehouda with a cast of local residents. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1971.

Credits: Director, writers, Jean-Louis Bertucelli, Jean Duvignaud ; photography, Andreas Winding.
Cast: Leila Shanna.

results.title: Remorques = Stormy Waters
results.brief_description:
The captain of a tugboat is happily married but, when he rescues a boat from stormy waters, he falls in love with the wife of its captain. He leaves her to keep a vigil at the bedside of his own wife who is mortally ill. An intimate and perceptive study of passion and the nature of fidelity which benefits from a Prevert script and a trio of France’s top stars. Filmed partly on location in Brest, work began in 1939, was hampered by the restrictions imposed by the Nazis and was completed 2 years later in a Paris studio.

Credits: Producer, Roland Tual ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writer, Jacques Prevert ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Roland Manuel ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; assistant director, Louis Daquin.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Michele Morgan, Madeleine Renaud, Fernand Ledoux, Jean Marchat, Nane Germon, Charles Blavette, Alain Cuny.

results.title: Remontons les Champs-Elysees = Let's Walk Back Up to the Champs-Elysees
results.creator_credit: Guy Lacourt, Serge Sandberg and Robert Bibal
results.brief_description:
In order to break the routine of his lessons, a school teacher decides to tell his pupils the story of the Champs-Elysees, from the Renaissance to Napoleon III. This light historical comedy is a pretext for Guitry to play five roles and to play games with historical facts and famous characters.

Credits: Producers, Guy Lacourt, Serge Sandberg ; directors, Robert Bibal, Sacha Guitry ; writer, Sacha Guitry ; photography, Jean Bachelet ; music, Adolphe Borchard ; stills photographer, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Sacha Guitry, Jean Davy, Jacqueline Delubac, Jane Marken, Mila Parely, Jeanne Boitel, Lucien Baroux.

results.title: Remodelling milk
results.brief_description: Australian research into the behaviour of milk proteins during heating and mixing has led to new techniques for processing stable skim-milk powders rich in protein. This powder can be transported relatively cheaply to recombining plants in tropical areas, where it is mixed with anhydrous milk fat and water, with or without sugar, to produce sweetened condensed milk or unsweetened evaporated milk. Traces the recombining techniques from pilot plant to full-scale commercial production.

results.title: Remembrance: Reverberation [exhibition documentation]
results.brief_description:
“Remembrance: Reverberation” was an exhibition held at ACMI Screen Gallery, 27 June 2003 - 31 August 2003. See Exhibition activity file record “Remembrance: Reverberation” (ID 12) for more information.
Are memories like movies? Can they be recorded? Can you capture their yearning, their dread, their jubilation? Featuring spellbinding artworks by leading artists from around the world in ACMI’s acclaimed screen gallery, Remembrance reveals how deeply our memories can move us.

An unforgettable experience that draws on the visitors’ own memories, Remembrance will affect everyone in unique and unexpected ways. Evoking and challenging the intimate memories that sustain and shape our past, present and future, Remembrance immerses the visitor in explorations from the romantic to the confessional, from the spiritual to the taboo.
